Jude the Obscure
by Thomas Hardy

9.text:
"Yea, many there be that have run out of their
wits for women, and become servants for their

15.text:
sakes.
Many also have perished, have erred, and sinned,

19.text:
for women.... O ye men, how can it be but
women should be strong, seeing they do thus?"—ESDRAS.

29.text:
The schoolmaster was leaving the village,
and everybody seemed sorry. The miller at

34.text:
Cresscombe lent him the small white tilted
cart and horse to carry his goods to the city

40.text:
of his destination, about twenty miles off,
such a vehicle proving of quite sufficient

45.text:
size for the departing teacher's effects.
For the schoolhouse had been partly furnished

50.text:
by the managers, and the only cumbersome article
possessed by the master, in addition to the

55.text:
packing-case of books, was a cottage piano
that he had bought at an auction during the

60.text:
year in which he thought of learning instrumental
music.

63.text:
But the enthusiasm having waned he had never
acquired any skill in playing, and the purchased

68.text:
article had been a perpetual trouble to him
ever since in moving house.

73.text:
The rector had gone away for the day, being
a man who disliked the sight of changes.

78.text:
He did not mean to return till the evening,
when the new school-teacher would have arrived

82.text:
and settled in, and everything would be smooth
again.

86.text:
The blacksmith, the farm bailiff, and the
schoolmaster himself were standing in perplexed

91.text:
attitudes in the parlour before the instrument.
The master had remarked that even if he got

96.text:
it into the cart he should not know what to
do with it on his arrival at Christminster,

101.text:
the city he was bound for, since he was only
going into temporary lodgings just at first.

108.text:
A little boy of eleven, who had been thoughtfully
assisting in the packing, joined the group

112.text:
of men, and as they rubbed their chins he
spoke up, blushing at the sound of his own

117.text:
voice: "Aunt have got a great fuel-house,
and it could be put there, perhaps, till you've

123.text:
found a place to settle in, sir."
"A proper good notion," said the blacksmith.

129.text:
It was decided that a deputation should wait
on the boy's aunt—an old maiden resident—and

135.text:
ask her if she would house the piano till
Mr. Phillotson should send for it.

139.text:
The smith and the bailiff started to see about
the practicability of the suggested shelter,

143.text:
and the boy and the schoolmaster were left
standing alone.

147.text:
"Sorry I am going, Jude?" asked the latter
kindly.

152.text:
Tears rose into the boy's eyes, for he was
not among the regular day scholars, who came

158.text:
unromantically close to the schoolmaster's
life, but one who had attended the night school

162.text:
only during the present teacher's term of
office.

166.text:
The regular scholars, if the truth must be
told, stood at the present moment afar off,

171.text:
like certain historic disciples, indisposed
to any enthusiastic volunteering of aid.

178.text:
The boy awkwardly opened the book he held
in his hand, which Mr. Phillotson had bestowed

183.text:
on him as a parting gift, and admitted that
he was sorry.

187.text:
"So am I," said Mr. Phillotson.
"Why do you go, sir?" asked the boy.

194.text:
"Ah—that would be a long story.
You wouldn't understand my reasons, Jude.

199.text:
You will, perhaps, when you are older."
"I think I should now, sir."

205.text:
"Well—don't speak of this everywhere.
You know what a university is, and a university

210.text:
degree?
It is the necessary hallmark of a man who

213.text:
wants to do anything in teaching.
My scheme, or dream, is to be a university

219.text:
graduate, and then to be ordained.
By going to live at Christminster, or near

223.text:
it, I shall be at headquarters, so to speak,
and if my scheme is practicable at all, I

229.text:
consider that being on the spot will afford
me a better chance of carrying it out than

233.text:
I should have elsewhere."
The smith and his companion returned.

238.text:
Old Miss Fawley's fuel-house was dry, and
eminently practicable; and she seemed willing

242.text:
to give the instrument standing-room there.
It was accordingly left in the school till

247.text:
the evening, when more hands would be available
for removing it; and the schoolmaster gave

252.text:
a final glance round.
The boy Jude assisted in loading some small

258.text:
articles, and at nine o'clock Mr. Phillotson
mounted beside his box of books and other

263.text:
_impedimenta_, and bade his friends good-bye.
"I shan't forget you, Jude," he said, smiling,

269.text:
as the cart moved off. "Be a good boy, remember;
and be kind to animals and birds, and read

275.text:
all you can.
And if ever you come to Christminster remember

279.text:
you hunt me out for old acquaintance' sake."
The cart creaked across the green, and disappeared

286.text:
round the corner by the rectory-house. The
boy returned to the draw-well at the edge

290.text:
of the greensward, where he had left his buckets
when he went to help his patron and teacher

295.text:
in the loading.
There was a quiver in his lip now and after

300.text:
opening the well-cover to begin lowering the
bucket he paused and leant with his forehead

305.text:
and arms against the framework, his face wearing
the fixity of a thoughtful child's who has

310.text:
felt the pricks of life somewhat before his
time.

314.text:
The well into which he was looking was as
ancient as the village itself, and from his

319.text:
present position appeared as a long circular
perspective ending in a shining disk of quivering

324.text:
water at a distance of a hundred feet down.
There was a lining of green moss near the

331.text:
top, and nearer still the hart's-tongue fern.
He said to himself, in the melodramatic tones

337.text:
of a whimsical boy, that the schoolmaster
had drawn at that well scores of times on

342.text:
a morning like this, and would never draw
there any more.

345.text:
"I've seen him look down into it, when he
was tired with his drawing, just as I do now,

351.text:
and when he rested a bit before carrying the
buckets home! But he was too clever to bide

356.text:
here any longer—a small sleepy place like
this!"

360.text:
A tear rolled from his eye into the depths
of the well.

364.text:
The morning was a little foggy, and the boy's
breathing unfurled itself as a thicker fog

368.text:
upon the still and heavy air.
His thoughts were interrupted by a sudden

373.text:
outcry:
"Bring on that water, will ye, you idle young

377.text:
harlican!"
It came from an old woman who had emerged

380.text:
from her door towards the garden gate of a
green-thatched cottage not far off.

386.text:
The boy quickly waved a signal of assent,
drew the water with what was a great effort

390.text:
for one of his stature, landed and emptied
the big bucket into his own pair of smaller

395.text:
ones, and pausing a moment for breath, started
with them across the patch of clammy greensward

401.text:
whereon the well stood—nearly in the centre
of the little village, or rather hamlet of

407.text:
Marygreen.
It was as old-fashioned as it was small, and

411.text:
it rested in the lap of an undulating upland
adjoining the North Wessex downs.

416.text:
Old as it was, however, the well-shaft was
probably the only relic of the local history

422.text:
that remained absolutely unchanged.
Many of the thatched and dormered dwelling-houses

428.text:
had been pulled down of late years, and many
trees felled on the green.

432.text:
Above all, the original church, hump-backed,
wood-turreted, and quaintly hipped, had been

438.text:
taken down, and either cracked up into heaps
of road-metal in the lane, or utilized as

444.text:
pig-sty walls, garden seats, guard-stones
to fences, and rockeries in the flower-beds

449.text:
of the neighbourhood.
In place of it a tall new building of modern

454.text:
Gothic design, unfamiliar to English eyes,
had been erected on a new piece of ground

459.text:
by a certain obliterator of historic records
who had run down from London and back in a

464.text:
day.
The site whereon so long had stood the ancient

468.text:
temple to the Christian divinities was not
even recorded on the green and level grass-plot

473.text:
that had immemorially been the churchyard,
the obliterated graves being commemorated

479.text:
by eighteen-penny cast-iron crosses warranted
to last five years.

489.text:
II
Slender as was Jude Fawley's frame he bore

496.text:
the two brimming house-buckets of water to
the cottage without resting.

501.text:
Over the door was a little rectangular piece
of blue board, on which was painted in yellow

506.text:
letters, "Drusilla Fawley, Baker."
Within the little lead panes of the window—this

512.text:
being one of the few old houses left—were
five bottles of sweets, and three buns on

517.text:
a plate of the willow pattern.
While emptying the buckets at the back of

521.text:
the house he could hear an animated conversation
in progress within-doors between his great-aunt,

527.text:
the Drusilla of the sign-board, and some other
villagers.

531.text:
Having seen the school-master depart, they
were summing up particulars of the event,

536.text:
and indulging in predictions of his future.
"And who's he?" asked one, comparatively a

542.text:
stranger, when the boy entered.
"Well ye med ask it, Mrs. Williams.

547.text:
He's my great-nephew—come since you was
last this way."

551.text:
The old inhabitant who answered was a tall,
gaunt woman, who spoke tragically on the most

556.text:
trivial subject, and gave a phrase of her
conversation to each auditor in turn.

561.text:
"He come from Mellstock, down in South Wessex,
about a year ago—worse luck for 'n, Belinda"

567.text:
(turning to the right) "where his father was
living, and was took wi' the shakings for

571.text:
death, and died in two days, as you know,
Caroline" (turning to the left). "It would

578.text:
ha' been a blessing if Goddy-mighty had took
thee too, wi' thy mother and father, poor

582.text:
useless boy!
But I've got him here to stay with me till

585.text:
I can see what's to be done with un, though
I am obliged to let him earn any penny he

590.text:
can.
Just now he's a-scaring of birds for Farmer

592.text:
Troutham. It keeps him out of mischty.
Why do ye turn away, Jude?" she continued,

598.text:
as the boy, feeling the impact of their glances
like slaps upon his face, moved aside.

605.text:
The local washerwoman replied that it was
perhaps a very good plan of Miss or Mrs. Fawley's

610.text:
(as they called her indifferently) to have
him with her—"to kip 'ee company in your

616.text:
loneliness, fetch water, shet the winder-shetters
o' nights, and help in the bit o' baking."

621.text:
Miss Fawley doubted it....
"Why didn't ye get the schoolmaster to take

625.text:
'ee to Christminster wi' un, and make a scholar
of 'ee," she continued, in frowning pleasantry.

630.text:
"I'm sure he couldn't ha' took a better one.
The boy is crazy for books, that he is.

636.text:
It runs in our family rather.
His cousin Sue is just the same—so I've

641.text:
heard; but I have not seen the child for years,
though she was born in this place, within

646.text:
these four walls, as it happened.
My niece and her husband, after they were

650.text:
married, didn' get a house of their own for
some year or more; and then they only had

655.text:
one till—Well, I won't go into that.
Jude, my child, don't you ever marry.

661.text:
'Tisn't for the Fawleys to take that step
any more.

664.text:
She, their only one, was like a child o' my
own, Belinda, till the split come!

669.text:
Ah, that a little maid should know such changes!"
Jude, finding the general attention again

676.text:
centering on himself, went out to the bakehouse,
where he ate the cake provided for his breakfast.

682.text:
The end of his spare time had now arrived,
and emerging from the garden by getting over

687.text:
the hedge at the back he pursued a path northward,
till he came to a wide and lonely depression

692.text:
in the general level of the upland, which
was sown as a corn-field.

696.text:
This vast concave was the scene of his labours
for Mr Troutham the farmer, and he descended

702.text:
into the midst of it.
The brown surface of the field went right

707.text:
up towards the sky all round, where it was
lost by degrees in the mist that shut out

711.text:
the actual verge and accentuated the solitude.
The only marks on the uniformity of the scene

717.text:
were a rick of last year's produce standing
in the midst of the arable, the rooks that

722.text:
rose at his approach, and the path athwart
the fallow by which he had come, trodden now

727.text:
by he hardly knew whom, though once by many
of his own dead family.

731.text:
"How ugly it is here!" he murmured.
The fresh harrow-lines seemed to stretch like

738.text:
the channellings in a piece of new corduroy,
lending a meanly utilitarian air to the expanse,

744.text:
taking away its gradations, and depriving
it of all history beyond that of the few recent

750.text:
months, though to every clod and stone there
really attached associations enough and to

754.text:
spare—echoes of songs from ancient harvest-days,
of spoken words, and of sturdy deeds.

761.text:
Every inch of ground had been the site, first
or last, of energy, gaiety, horse-play, bickerings,

768.text:
weariness.
Groups of gleaners had squatted in the sun

771.text:
on every square yard. Love-matches that had
populated the adjoining hamlet had been made

776.text:
up there between reaping and carrying.
Under the hedge which divided the field from

781.text:
a distant plantation girls had given themselves
to lovers who would not turn their heads to

786.text:
look at them by the next harvest; and in that
ancient cornfield many a man had made love-promises

792.text:
to a woman at whose voice he had trembled
by the next seed-time after fulfilling them

797.text:
in the church adjoining.
But this neither Jude nor the rooks around

802.text:
him considered. For them it was a lonely place,
possessing, in the one view, only the quality

808.text:
of a work-ground, and in the other that of
a granary good to feed in.

814.text:
The boy stood under the rick before mentioned,
and every few seconds used his clacker or

819.text:
rattle briskly.
At each clack the rooks left off pecking,

823.text:
and rose and went away on their leisurely
wings, burnished like tassets of mail, afterwards

828.text:
wheeling back and regarding him warily, and
descending to feed at a more respectful distance.

835.text:
He sounded the clacker till his arm ached,
and at length his heart grew sympathetic with

839.text:
the birds' thwarted desires.
They seemed, like himself, to be living in

843.text:
a world which did not want them.
Why should he frighten them away?

847.text:
They took upon more and more the aspect of
gentle friends and pensioners—the only friends

853.text:
he could claim as being in the least degree
interested in him, for his aunt had often

857.text:
told him that she was not.
He ceased his rattling, and they alighted

861.text:
anew.
"Poor little dears!" said Jude, aloud.

865.text:
"You SHALL have some dinner— you shall.
There is enough for us all.

871.text:
Farmer Troutham can afford to let you have
some.

873.text:
Eat, then my dear little birdies, and make
a good meal!"

876.text:
They stayed and ate, inky spots on the nut-brown
soil, and Jude enjoyed their appetite.

883.text:
A magic thread of fellow-feeling united his
own life with theirs.

887.text:
Puny and sorry as those lives were, they much
resembled his own.

892.text:
His clacker he had by this time thrown away
from him, as being a mean and sordid instrument,

898.text:
offensive both to the birds and to himself
as their friend.

902.text:
All at once he became conscious of a smart
blow upon his buttocks, followed by a loud

907.text:
clack, which announced to his surprised senses
that the clacker had been the instrument of

911.text:
offence used.
The birds and Jude started up simultaneously,

916.text:
and the dazed eyes of the latter beheld the
farmer in person, the great Troutham himself,

922.text:
his red face glaring down upon Jude's cowering
frame, the clacker swinging in his hand.

928.text:
"So it's 'Eat my dear birdies,' is it, young
man?

932.text:
'Eat, dear birdies,' indeed!
I'll tickle your breeches, and see if you

936.text:
say, 'Eat, dear birdies,' again in a hurry!
And you've been idling at the schoolmaster's

940.text:
too, instead of coming here, ha'n't ye, hey?
That's how you earn your sixpence a day for

944.text:
keeping the rooks off my corn!"
Whilst saluting Jude's ears with this impassioned

949.text:
rhetoric, Troutham had seized his left hand
with his own left, and swinging his slim frame

954.text:
round him at arm's-length, again struck Jude
on the hind parts with the flat side of Jude's

959.text:
own rattle, till the field echoed with the
blows, which were delivered once or twice

963.text:
at each revolution.
"Don't 'ee, sir—please don't 'ee!" cried

967.text:
the whirling child, as helpless under the
centrifugal tendency of his person as a hooked

972.text:
fish swinging to land, and beholding the hill,
the rick, the plantation, the path, and the

978.text:
rooks going round and round him in an amazing
circular race.

982.text:
"I—I sir—only meant that—there was a
good crop in the ground—I saw 'em sow it—and

988.text:
the rooks could have a little bit for dinner—and
you wouldn't miss it, sir—and Mr. Phillotson

992.text:
said I was to be kind to 'em—oh, oh, oh!"
This truthful explanation seemed to exasperate

998.text:
the farmer even more than if Jude had stoutly
denied saying anything at all, and he still

1004.text:
smacked the whirling urchin, the clacks of
the instrument continuing to resound all across

1008.text:
the field and as far as the ears of distant
workers—who gathered thereupon that Jude

1014.text:
was pursuing his business of clacking with
great assiduity—and echoing from the brand-new

1018.text:
church tower just behind the mist, towards
the building of which structure the farmer

1023.text:
had largely subscribed, to testify his love
for God and man.

1029.text:
Presently Troutham grew tired of his punitive
task, and depositing the quivering boy on

1033.text:
his legs, took a sixpence from his pocket
and gave it him in payment for his day's work,

1038.text:
telling him to go home and never let him see
him in one of those fields again.

1043.text:
Jude leaped out of arm's reach, and walked
along the trackway weeping—not from the

1047.text:
pain, though that was keen enough; not from
the perception of the flaw in the terrestrial

1053.text:
scheme, by which what was good for God's birds
was bad for God's gardener; but with the awful

1058.text:
sense that he had wholly disgraced himself
before he had been a year in the parish, and

1063.text:
hence might be a burden to his great-aunt
for life.

1067.text:
With this shadow on his mind he did not care
to show himself in the village, and went homeward

1071.text:
by a roundabout track behind a high hedge
and across a pasture.

1076.text:
Here he beheld scores of coupled earthworms
lying half their length on the surface of

1081.text:
the damp ground, as they always did in such
weather at that time of the year.

1085.text:
It was impossible to advance in regular steps
without crushing some of them at each tread.

1090.text:
Though Farmer Troutham had just hurt him,
he was a boy who could not himself bear to

1095.text:
hurt anything.
He had never brought home a nest of young

1098.text:
birds without lying awake in misery half the
night after, and often reinstating them and

1104.text:
the nest in their original place the next
morning.

1107.text:
He could scarcely bear to see trees cut down
or lopped, from a fancy that it hurt them;

1112.text:
and late pruning, when the sap was up and
the tree bled profusely, had been a positive

1117.text:
grief to him in his infancy.
This weakness of character, as it may be called,

1124.text:
suggested that he was the sort of man who
was born to ache a good deal before the fall

1128.text:
of the curtain upon his unnecessary life should
signify that all was well with him again.

1135.text:
He carefully picked his way on tiptoe among
the earthworms, without killing a single one.

1141.text:
On entering the cottage he found his aunt
selling a penny loaf to a little girl, and

1145.text:
when the customer was gone she said, "Well,
how do you come to be back here in the middle

1151.text:
of the morning like this?"
"I'm turned away."

1154.text:
"What?"
"Mr. Troutham have turned me away because

1157.text:
I let the rooks have a few peckings of corn.
And there's my wages—the last I shall ever

1163.text:
hae!"
He threw the sixpence tragically on the table.

1166.text:
"Ah!" said his aunt, suspending her breath.
And she opened upon him a lecture on how she

1172.text:
would now have him all the spring upon her
hands doing nothing.

1176.text:
"If you can't skeer birds, what can ye do?
There! don't ye look so deedy!

1182.text:
Farmer Troutham is not so much better than
myself, come to that.

1185.text:
But 'tis as Job said, 'Now they that are younger
than I have me in derision, whose fathers

1190.text:
I would have disdained to have set with the
dogs of my flock.'

1193.text:
His father was my father's journeyman, anyhow,
and I must have been a fool to let 'ee go

1198.text:
to work for 'n, which I shouldn't ha' done
but to keep 'ee out of mischty."

1202.text:
More angry with Jude for demeaning her by
coming there than for dereliction of duty,

1207.text:
she rated him primarily from that point of
view, and only secondarily from a moral one.

1212.text:
"Not that you should have let the birds eat
what Farmer Troutham planted.

1216.text:
Of course you was wrong in that.
Jude, Jude, why didstn't go off with that

1220.text:
schoolmaster of thine to Christminster or
somewhere? But, oh no—poor or'nary child—there

1226.text:
never was any sprawl on thy side of the family,
and never will be!"

1230.text:
"Where is this beautiful city, Aunt—this
place where Mr. Phillotson is gone to?" asked

1235.text:
the boy, after meditating in silence.
"Lord! you ought to know where the city of

1240.text:
Christminster is.
Near a score of miles from here.

1243.text:
It is a place much too good for you ever to
have much to do with, poor boy, I'm a-thinking."

1249.text:
"And will Mr. Phillotson always be there?"
"How can I tell?"

1253.text:
"Could I go to see him?"
"Lord, no!

1257.text:
You didn't grow up hereabout, or you wouldn't
ask such as that.

1260.text:
We've never had anything to do with folk in
Christminster, nor folk in Christminster with

1264.text:
we."
Jude went out, and, feeling more than ever

1268.text:
his existence to be an undemanded one, he
lay down upon his back on a heap of litter

1273.text:
near the pig-sty.
The fog had by this time become more translucent,

1279.text:
and the position of the sun could be seen
through it.

1282.text:
He pulled his straw hat over his face, and
peered through the interstices of the plaiting

1286.text:
at the white brightness, vaguely reflecting.
Growing up brought responsibilities, he found.

1293.text:
Events did not rhyme quite as he had thought.
Nature's logic was too horrid for him to care

1298.text:
for. That mercy towards one set of creatures
was cruelty towards another sickened his sense

1304.text:
of harmony.
As you got older, and felt yourself to be

1308.text:
at the centre of your time, and not at a point
in its circumference, as you had felt when

1313.text:
you were little, you were seized with a sort
of shuddering, he perceived.

1318.text:
All around you there seemed to be something
glaring, garish, rattling, and the noises

1322.text:
and glares hit upon the little cell called
your life, and shook it, and warped it.

1328.text:
If he could only prevent himself growing up!
He did not want to be a man.

1333.text:
Then, like the natural boy, he forgot his
despondency, and sprang up. During the remainder

1338.text:
of the morning he helped his aunt, and in
the afternoon, when there was nothing more

1342.text:
to be done, he went into the village.
Here he asked a man whereabouts Christminster

1349.text:
Oh, well, out by there yonder; though I've
never bin there—not I.

1356.text:
I've never had any business at such a place."
The man pointed north-eastward, in the very

1361.text:
direction where lay that field in which Jude
had so disgraced himself.

1364.text:
There was something unpleasant about the coincidence
for the moment, but the fearsomeness of this

1369.text:
fact rather increased his curiosity about
the city.

1373.text:
The farmer had said he was never to be seen
in that field again; yet Christminster lay

1378.text:
across it, and the path was a public one.
So, stealing out of the hamlet, he descended

1383.text:
into the same hollow which had witnessed his

8363.text:
It was one which he had had specially taken
and framed by a local man in bird's-eye maple,

8368.text:
as a present for Arabella, and had duly given
her on their wedding-day.

8373.text:
On the back was still to be read, "_Jude to
Arabella_," with the date.

8379.text:
She must have thrown it in with the rest of
her property at the auction.

8382.text:
"Oh," said the broker, seeing him look at
this and the other articles in the heap, and

8388.text:
not perceiving that the portrait was of himself:
"It is a small lot of stuff that was knocked

8392.text:
down to me at a cottage sale out on the road
to Marygreen.

8396.text:
The frame is a very useful one, if you take
out the likeness. You shall have it for a

8400.text:
shilling."
The utter death of every tender sentiment

8404.text:
in his wife, as brought home to him by this
mute and undesigned evidence of her sale of

8409.text:
his portrait and gift, was the conclusive
little stroke required to demolish all sentiment

8414.text:
in him.
He paid the shilling, took the photograph

8417.text:
away with him, and burnt it, frame and all,
when he reached his lodging.

8422.text:
Two or three days later he heard that Arabella
and her parents had departed.

8427.text:
He had sent a message offering to see her
for a formal leave-taking, but she had said

8432.text:
that it would be better otherwise, since she
was bent on going, which perhaps was true.

8438.text:
On the evening following their emigration,
when his day's work was done, he came out

8442.text:
of doors after supper, and strolled in the
starlight along the too familiar road towards

8447.text:
the upland whereon had been experienced the
chief emotions of his life.

8452.text:
It seemed to be his own again.
He could not realize himself.

8457.text:
On the old track he seemed to be a boy still,
hardly a day older than when he had stood

8462.text:
dreaming at the top of that hill, inwardly
fired for the first time with ardours for

8467.text:
Christminster and scholarship.
"Yet I am a man," he said.

8472.text:
"I have a wife.
More, I have arrived at the still riper stage

8476.text:
of having disagreed with her, disliked her,
had a scuffle with her, and parted from her."

8482.text:
He remembered then that he was standing not
far from the spot at which the parting between

8486.text:
his father and his mother was said to have
occurred.

8489.text:
A little further on was the summit whence
Christminster, or what he had taken for that

8494.text:
city, had seemed to be visible.
A milestone, now as always, stood at the roadside

8500.text:
hard by.
Jude drew near it, and felt rather than read

8505.text:
the mileage to the city.
He remembered that once on his way home he

8510.text:
had proudly cut with his keen new chisel an
inscription on the back of that milestone,

8515.text:
embodying his aspirations. It had been done
in the first week of his apprenticeship, before

8520.text:
he had been diverted from his purposes by
an unsuitable woman.

8524.text:
He wondered if the inscription were legible
still, and going to the back of the milestone

8529.text:
brushed away the nettles.
By the light of a match he could still discern

8533.text:
what he had cut so enthusiastically so long
ago:

8536.text:
THITHER J. F. [with a pointing finger]
The sight of it, unimpaired, within its screen

8543.text:
of grass and nettles, lit in his soul a spark
of the old fire.

8549.text:
Surely his plan should be to move onward through
good and ill—to avoid morbid sorrow even

8554.text:
though he did see uglinesses in the world?
_Bene agere et loetari_—to do good cheerfully—which

8562.text:
he had heard to be the philosophy of one Spinoza,
might be his own even now.

8568.text:
He might battle with his evil star, and follow
out his original intention.

8573.text:
By moving to a spot a little way off he uncovered
the horizon in a north-easterly direction.

8579.text:
There actually rose the faint halo, a small
dim nebulousness, hardly recognizable save

8585.text:
by the eye of faith. It was enough for him.
He would go to Christminster as soon as the

8590.text:
term of his apprenticeship expired.
He returned to his lodgings in a better mood,

8610.text:
"Save his own soul he hath no star."—SWINBURNE.
"Notitiam primosque gradus vicinia fecit;

8626.text:
The next noteworthy move in Jude's life was
that in which he appeared gliding steadily

8631.text:
onward through a dusky landscape of some three
years' later leafage than had graced his courtship

8636.text:
of Arabella, and the disruption of his coarse
conjugal life with her.

8641.text:
He was walking towards Christminster City,
at a point a mile or two to the south-west

8645.text:
of it.
He had at last found himself clear of Marygreen

8649.text:
and Alfredston: he was out of his apprenticeship,
and with his tools at his back seemed to be

8655.text:
in the way of making a new start—the start
to which, barring the interruption involved

8660.text:
in his intimacy and married experience with
Arabella, he had been looking forward for

8665.text:
about ten years.
Jude would now have been described as a young

8669.text:
man with a forcible, meditative, and earnest
rather than handsome cast of countenance.

8676.text:
He was of dark complexion, with dark harmonizing
eyes, and he wore a closely trimmed black

8681.text:
beard of more advanced growth than is usual
at his age; this, with his great mass of black

8688.text:
curly hair, was some trouble to him in combing
and washing out the stone-dust that settled

8693.text:
on it in the pursuit of his trade.
His capabilities in the latter, having been

8698.text:
acquired in the country, were of an all-round
sort, including monumental stone-cutting,

8703.text:
gothic free-stone work for the restoration
of churches, and carving of a general kind.

8709.text:
In London he would probably have become specialized
and have made himself a "moulding mason,"

8715.text:
a "foliage sculptor"—perhaps a "statuary."
He had that afternoon driven in a cart from

8720.text:
Alfredston to the village nearest the city
in this direction, and was now walking the

8725.text:
remaining four miles rather from choice than
from necessity, having always fancied himself

8731.text:
arriving thus.
The ultimate impulse to come had had a curious

8735.text:
origin—one more nearly related to the emotional
side of him than to the intellectual, as is

8741.text:
often the case with young men.
One day while in lodgings at Alfredston he

8746.text:
had gone to Marygreen to see his old aunt,
and had observed between the brass candlesticks

8751.text:
on her mantlepiece the photograph of a pretty
girlish face, in a broad hat with radiating

8757.text:
folds under the brim like the rays of a halo.
He had asked who she was.

8763.text:
His grand-aunt had gruffly replied that she
was his cousin Sue Bridehead, of the inimical

8768.text:
branch of the family; and on further questioning
the old woman had replied that the girl lived

8773.text:
in Christminster, though she did not know
where, or what she was doing.

8778.text:
His aunt would not give him the photograph.
But it haunted him; and ultimately formed

8783.text:
a quickening ingredient in his latent intent
of following his friend the school master

8788.text:
thither.
He now paused at the top of a crooked and

8791.text:
gentle declivity, and obtained his first near
view of the city.

8797.text:
Grey-stoned and dun-roofed, it stood within
hail of the Wessex border, and almost with

8802.text:
the tip of one small toe within it, at the
northernmost point of the crinkled line along

8807.text:
which the leisurely Thames strokes the fields
of that ancient kingdom.

8812.text:
The buildings now lay quiet in the sunset,
a vane here and there on their many spires

8817.text:
and domes giving sparkle to a picture of sober
secondary and tertiary hues.

8824.text:
Reaching the bottom he moved along the level
way between pollard willows growing indistinct

8828.text:
in the twilight, and soon confronted the outmost
lamps of the town—some of those lamps which

8834.text:
had sent into the sky the gleam and glory
that caught his strained gaze in his days

8840.text:
of dreaming, so many years ago.
They winked their yellow eyes at him dubiously,

8846.text:
and as if, though they had been awaiting him
all these years in disappointment at his tarrying,

8851.text:
they did not much want him now.
He was a species of Dick Whittington whose

8856.text:
spirit was touched to finer issues than a
mere material gain.

8861.text:
He went along the outlying streets with the
cautious tread of an explorer.

8866.text:
He saw nothing of the real city in the suburbs
on this side.

8869.text:
His first want being a lodging he scrutinized
carefully such localities as seemed to offer

8874.text:
on inexpensive terms the modest type of accommodation
he demanded; and after inquiry took a room

8881.text:
in a suburb nicknamed "Beersheba," though
he did not know this at the time.

8887.text:
Here he installed himself, and having had
some tea sallied forth.

8892.text:
It was a windy, whispering, moonless night.
To guide himself he opened under a lamp a

8898.text:
map he had brought.
The breeze ruffled and fluttered it, but he

8902.text:
could see enough to decide on the direction
he should take to reach the heart of the place.

8907.text:
After many turnings he came up to the first
ancient mediæval pile that he had encountered.

8914.text:
It was a college, as he could see by the gateway.
He entered it, walked round, and penetrated

8919.text:
to dark corners which no lamplight reached.
Close to this college was another; and a little

8925.text:
further on another; and then he began to be
encircled as it were with the breath and sentiment

8932.text:
of the venerable city.
When he passed objects out of harmony with

8935.text:
its general expression he allowed his eyes
to slip over them as if he did not see them.

8941.text:
A bell began clanging, and he listened till
a hundred-and-one strokes had sounded.

8947.text:
He must have made a mistake, he thought: it
was meant for a hundred.

8951.text:
When the gates were shut, and he could no
longer get into the quadrangles, he rambled

8956.text:
under the walls and doorways, feeling with
his fingers the contours of their mouldings

8961.text:
and carving.
The minutes passed, fewer and fewer people

8965.text:
were visible, and still he serpentined among
the shadows, for had he not imagined these

8971.text:
scenes through ten bygone years, and what
mattered a night's rest for once?

8977.text:
High against the black sky the flash of a
lamp would show crocketed pinnacles and indented

8983.text:
battlements.
Down obscure alleys, apparently never trodden

8986.text:
now by the foot of man, and whose very existence
seemed to be forgotten, there would jut into

8992.text:
the path porticoes, oriels, doorways of enriched
and florid middle-age design, their extinct

8998.text:
air being accentuated by the rottenness of
the stones.

9002.text:
It seemed impossible that modern thought could
house itself in such decrepit and superseded

9007.text:
chambers.
Knowing not a human being here, Jude began

9012.text:
to be impressed with the isolation of his
own personality, as with a self-spectre, the

9017.text:
sensation being that of one who walked but
could not make himself seen or heard.

9022.text:
He drew his breath pensively, and, seeming
thus almost his own ghost, gave his thoughts

9028.text:
to the other ghostly presences with which
the nooks were haunted.

9032.text:
During the interval of preparation for this
venture, since his wife and furniture's uncompromising

9037.text:
disappearance into space, he had read and
learnt almost all that could be read and learnt

9042.text:
by one in his position, of the worthies who
had spent their youth within these reverend

9047.text:
walls, and whose souls had haunted them in
their maturer age.

9052.text:
Some of them, by the accidents of his reading,
loomed out in his fancy disproportionately

9057.text:
large by comparison with the rest.
The brushings of the wind against the angles,

9062.text:
buttresses, and door-jambs were as the passing
of these only other inhabitants, the tappings

9067.text:
of each ivy leaf on its neighbour were as
the mutterings of their mournful souls, the

9072.text:
shadows as their thin shapes in nervous movement,
making him comrades in his solitude.

9078.text:
In the gloom it was as if he ran against them
without feeling their bodily frames.

9083.text:
The streets were now deserted, but on account
of these things he could not go in.

9089.text:
There were poets abroad, of early date and
of late, from the friend and eulogist of Shakespeare

9094.text:
down to him who has recently passed into silence,
and that musical one of the tribe who is still

9100.text:
among us.
Speculative philosophers drew along, not always

9104.text:
with wrinkled foreheads and hoary hair as
in framed portraits, but pink-faced, slim,

9110.text:
and active as in youth; modern divines sheeted
in their surplices, among whom the most real

9116.text:
to Jude Fawley were the founders of the religious
school called Tractarian; the well-known three,

9123.text:
the enthusiast, the poet, and the formularist,
the echoes of whose teachings had influenced

9128.text:
him even in his obscure home. A start of aversion
appeared in his fancy to move them at sight

9136.text:
of those other sons of the place, the form
in the full-bottomed wig, statesman, rake,

9141.text:
reasoner, and sceptic; the smoothly shaven
historian so ironically civil to Christianity;

9148.text:
with others of the same incredulous temper,
who knew each quad as well as the faithful,

9153.text:
and took equal freedom in haunting its cloisters.
He regarded the statesmen in their various

9158.text:
types, men of firmer movement and less dreamy
air; the scholar, the speaker, the plodder;

9165.text:
the man whose mind grew with his growth in
years, and the man whose mind contracted with

9170.text:
the same.
The scientists and philologists followed on

9174.text:
in his mind-sight in an odd impossible combination,
men of meditative faces, strained foreheads,

9181.text:
and weak-eyed as bats with constant research;
then official characters—such men as governor-generals

9188.text:
and lord-lieutenants, in whom he took little
interest; chief-justices and lord chancellors,

9195.text:
silent thin-lipped figures of whom he knew
barely the names.

9199.text:
A keener regard attached to the prelates,
by reason of his own former hopes.

9204.text:
Of them he had an ample band—some men of
heart, others rather men of head; he who apologized

9212.text:
for the Church in Latin; the saintly author
of the Evening Hymn; and near them the great

9218.text:
itinerant preacher, hymn-writer, and zealot,
shadowed like Jude by his matrimonial difficulties.

9225.text:
Jude found himself speaking out loud, holding
conversations with them as it were, like an

9230.text:
actor in a melodrama who apostrophizes the
audience on the other side of the footlights;

9235.text:
till he suddenly ceased with a start at his
absurdity.

9239.text:
Perhaps those incoherent words of the wanderer
were heard within the walls by some student

9244.text:
or thinker over his lamp; and he may have
raised his head, and wondered what voice it

9249.text:
was, and what it betokened.
Jude now perceived that, so far as solid flesh

9255.text:
went, he had the whole aged city to himself
with the exception of a belated townsman here

9260.text:
and there, and that he seemed to be catching
a cold.

9264.text:
A voice reached him out of the shade; a real
and local voice:

9269.text:
"You've been a-settin' a long time on that
plinth-stone, young man. What med you be up

9275.text:
to?"
It came from a policeman who had been observing

9277.text:
Jude without the latter observing him.
Jude went home and to bed, after reading up

9283.text:
a little about these men and their several
messages to the world from a book or two that

9288.text:
he had brought with him concerning the sons
of the university.

9292.text:
As he drew towards sleep various memorable
words of theirs that he had just been conning

9297.text:
seemed spoken by them in muttering utterances;
some audible, some unintelligible to him.

9303.text:
One of the spectres (who afterwards mourned
Christminster as "the home of lost causes,"

9309.text:
though Jude did not remember this) was now
apostrophizing her thus:

9313.text:
"Beautiful city! so venerable, so lovely,
so unravaged by the fierce intellectual life

9320.text:
of our century, so serene! ...
Her ineffable charm keeps ever calling us

9324.text:
to the true goal of all of us, to the ideal,
to perfection."

9330.text:
Another voice was that of the Corn Law convert,
whose phantom he had just seen in the quadrangle

9335.text:
with a great bell.
Jude thought his soul might have been shaping

9339.text:
the historic words of his master-speech:
"Sir, I may be wrong, but my impression is

9345.text:
that my duty towards a country threatened
with famine requires that that which has been

9349.text:
the ordinary remedy under all similar circumstances
should be resorted to now, namely, that there

9355.text:
should be free access to the food of man from
whatever quarter it may come...

9360.text:
Deprive me of office to-morrow, you can never
deprive me of the consciousness that I have

9363.text:
exercised the powers committed to me from
no corrupt or interested motives, from no

9368.text:
desire to gratify ambition, for no personal
gain."

9373.text:
Then the sly author of the immortal Chapter
on Christianity: "How shall we excuse the

9378.text:
supine inattention of the Pagan and philosophic
world, to those evidences [miracles] which

9384.text:
were presented by Omnipotence? ...
The sages of Greece and Rome turned aside

9388.text:
from the awful spectacle, and appeared unconscious
of any alterations in the moral or physical

9393.text:
government of the world."
Then the shade of the poet, the last of the

9398.text:
optimists:
How the world is made for each of us!

9402.text:
And each of the Many helps to recruit The
life of the race by a general plan.

9409.text:
Then one of the three enthusiasts he had seen
just now, the author of the _Apologia_:

9414.text:
"My argument was ... that absolute certitude
as to the truths of natural theology was the

9420.text:
result of an assemblage of concurring and
converging probabilities ... that probabilities

9424.text:
which did not reach to logical certainty might
create a mental certitude."

9430.text:
The second of them, no polemic, murmured quieter
things:

9434.text:
Why should we faint, and fear to live alone,
Since all alone, so Heaven has will'd, we

9441.text:
die?
He likewise heard some phrases spoken by the

9443.text:
phantom with the short face, the genial Spectator:
"When I look upon the tombs of the great,

9450.text:
every motion of envy dies in me; when I read
the epitaphs of the beautiful, every inordinate

9455.text:
desire goes out; when I meet with the grief
of parents upon a tombstone, my heart melts

9461.text:
with compassion; when I see the tombs of the
parents themselves, I consider the vanity

9466.text:
of grieving for those whom we must quickly
follow."

9470.text:
And lastly a gentle-voiced prelate spoke,
during whose meek, familiar rhyme, endeared

9476.text:
to him from earliest childhood, Jude fell
asleep:

9481.text:
Teach me to live, that I may dread The grave
as little as my bed. Teach me to die ...

9488.text:
He did not wake till morning.
The ghostly past seemed to have gone, and

9493.text:
everything spoke of to-day.
He started up in bed, thinking he had overslept

9497.text:
himself and then said:
"By Jove—I had quite forgotten my sweet-faced

9502.text:
cousin, and that she's here all the time!
... and my old schoolmaster, too."

9508.text:
His words about his schoolmaster had, perhaps,
less zest in them than his words concerning

9520.text:
II
Necessary meditations on the actual, including

9529.text:
the mean bread-and-cheese question, dissipated
the phantasmal for a while, and compelled

9534.text:
Jude to smother high thinkings under immediate
needs.

9539.text:
He had to get up, and seek for work, manual
work; the only kind deemed by many of its

9544.text:
professors to be work at all.
Passing out into the streets on this errand

9549.text:
he found that the colleges had treacherously
changed their sympathetic countenances: some

9554.text:
were pompous; some had put on the look of
family vaults above ground; something barbaric

9561.text:
loomed in the masonries of all.
The spirits of the great men had disappeared.

9567.text:
The numberless architectural pages around
him he read, naturally, less as an artist-critic

9572.text:
of their forms than as an artizan and comrade
of the dead handicraftsmen whose muscles had

9578.text:
actually executed those forms.
He examined the mouldings, stroked them as

9583.text:
one who knew their beginning, said they were
difficult or easy in the working, had taken

9588.text:
little or much time, were trying to the arm,
or convenient to the tool.

9593.text:
What at night had been perfect and ideal was
by day the more or less defective real.

9599.text:
Cruelties, insults, had, he perceived, been
inflicted on the aged erections.

9606.text:
The condition of several moved him as he would
have been moved by maimed sentient beings.

9612.text:
They were wounded, broken, sloughing off their
outer shape in the deadly struggle against

9617.text:
years, weather, and man.
The rottenness of these historical documents

9622.text:
reminded him that he was not, after all, hastening
on to begin the morning practically as he

9627.text:
had intended.
He had come to work, and to live by work,

9631.text:
and the morning had nearly gone.
It was, in one sense, encouraging to think

9636.text:
that in a place of crumbling stones there
must be plenty for one of his trade to do

9640.text:
in the business of renovation.
He asked his way to the workyard of the stone-mason

9645.text:
whose name had been given him at Alfredston;
and soon heard the familiar sound of the rubbers

9650.text:
and chisels.
The yard was a little centre of regeneration.

9655.text:
Here, with keen edges and smooth curves, were
forms in the exact likeness of those he had

9661.text:
seen abraded and time-eaten on the walls.
These were the ideas in modern prose which

9667.text:
the lichened colleges presented in old poetry.
Even some of those antiques might have been

9673.text:
called prose when they were new.
They had done nothing but wait, and had become

9677.text:
poetical. How easy to the smallest building;
how impossible to most men.

9684.text:
He asked for the foreman, and looked round
among the new traceries, mullions, transoms,

9688.text:
shafts, pinnacles, and battlements standing
on the bankers half worked, or waiting to

9693.text:
be removed.
They were marked by precision, mathematical

9697.text:
straightness, smoothness, exactitude: there
in the old walls were the broken lines of

9703.text:
the original idea; jagged curves, disdain
of precision, irregularity, disarray.

9710.text:
For a moment there fell on Jude a true illumination;
that here in the stone yard was a centre of

9716.text:
effort as worthy as that dignified by the
name of scholarly study within the noblest

9721.text:
of the colleges.
But he lost it under stress of his old idea.

9726.text:
He would accept any employment which might
be offered him on the strength of his late

9729.text:
employer's recommendation; but he would accept
it as a provisional thing only. This was his

9734.text:
form of the modern vice of unrest.
Moreover he perceived that at best only copying,

9741.text:
patching and imitating went on here; which
he fancied to be owing to some temporary and

9745.text:
local cause.
He did not at that time see that mediævalism

9749.text:
was as dead as a fern-leaf in a lump of coal;
that other developments were shaping in the

9755.text:
world around him, in which Gothic architecture
and its associations had no place.

9760.text:
The deadly animosity of contemporary logic
and vision towards so much of what he held

9765.text:
in reverence was not yet revealed to him.
Having failed to obtain work here as yet he

9771.text:
went away, and thought again of his cousin,
whose presence somewhere at hand he seemed

9776.text:
to feel in wavelets of interest, if not of
emotion.

9781.text:
How he wished he had that pretty portrait
of her!

9784.text:
At last he wrote to his aunt to send it.
She did so, with a request, however, that

9789.text:
he was not to bring disturbance into the family
by going to see the girl or her relations.

9793.text:
Jude, a ridiculously affectionate fellow,
promised nothing, put the photograph on the

9800.text:
mantel-piece, kissed it—he did not know
why—and felt more at home.

9805.text:
She seemed to look down and preside over his
tea.

9808.text:
It was cheering—the one thing uniting him
to the emotions of the living city.

9813.text:
There remained the schoolmaster—probably
now a reverend parson. But he could not possibly

9819.text:
hunt up such a respectable man just yet; so
raw and unpolished was his condition, so precarious

9826.text:
were his fortunes.
Thus he still remained in loneliness.

9831.text:
Although people moved round him he virtually
saw none.

9834.text:
Not as yet having mingled with the active
life of the place it was largely non-existent

9839.text:
to him. But the saints and prophets in the
window-tracery, the paintings in the galleries,

9844.text:
the statues, the busts, the gargoyles, the
corbel-heads—these seemed to breathe his

9850.text:
atmosphere.
Like all newcomers to a spot on which the

9853.text:
past is deeply graven he heard that past announcing
itself with an emphasis altogether unsuspected

9859.text:
by, and even incredible to, the habitual residents.
For many days he haunted the cloisters and

9866.text:
quadrangles of the colleges at odd minutes
in passing them, surprised by impish echoes

9872.text:
of his own footsteps, smart as the blows of
a mallet.

9876.text:
The Christminster "sentiment," as it had been
called, ate further and further into him;

9881.text:
till he probably knew more about those buildings
materially, artistically, and historically,

9887.text:
than any one of their inmates.
It was not till now, when he found himself

9892.text:
actually on the spot of his enthusiasm, that
Jude perceived how far away from the object

9897.text:
of that enthusiasm he really was.
Only a wall divided him from those happy young

9902.text:
contemporaries of his with whom he shared
a common mental life; men who had nothing

9908.text:
to do from morning till night but to read,
mark, learn, and inwardly digest.

9913.text:
Only a wall—but what a wall!
Every day, every hour, as he went in search

9919.text:
of labour, he saw them going and coming also,
rubbed shoulders with them, heard their voices,

9925.text:
marked their movements.
The conversation of some of the more thoughtful

9929.text:
among them seemed oftentimes, owing to his
long and persistent preparation for this place,

9935.text:
to be peculiarly akin to his own thoughts.
Yet he was as far from them as if he had been

9940.text:
at the antipodes.
Of course he was.

9944.text:
He was a young workman in a white blouse,
and with stone-dust in the creases of his

9949.text:
clothes; and in passing him they did not even
see him, or hear him, rather saw through him

9955.text:
as through a pane of glass at their familiars
beyond. Whatever they were to him, he to them

9961.text:
was not on the spot at all; and yet he had
fancied he would be close to their lives by

9966.text:
coming there.
But the future lay ahead after all; and if

9971.text:
he could only be so fortunate as to get into
good employment he would put up with the inevitable.

9977.text:
So he thanked God for his health and strength,
and took courage.

9981.text:
For the present he was outside the gates of
everything, colleges included: perhaps some

9985.text:
day he would be inside.
Those palaces of light and leading; he might

9990.text:
some day look down on the world through their
panes.

9994.text:
At length he did receive a message from the
stone-mason's yard—that a job was waiting

9999.text:
for him.
It was his first encouragement, and he closed

10003.text:
with the offer promptly.
He was young and strong, or he never could

10008.text:
have executed with such zest the undertakings
to which he now applied himself, since they

10013.text:
involved reading most of the night after working
all the day.

10018.text:
First he bought a shaded lamp for four and
six-pence, and obtained a good light.

10023.text:
Then he got pens, paper, and such other necessary
books as he had been unable to obtain elsewhere.

10029.text:
Then, to the consternation of his landlady,
he shifted all the furniture of his room—a

10034.text:
single one for living and sleeping—rigged
up a curtain on a rope across the middle,

10039.text:
to make a double chamber out of one, hung
up a thick blind that nobody should know how

10044.text:
he was curtailing the hours of sleep, laid
out his books, and sat down.

10048.text:
Having been deeply encumbered by marrying,
getting a cottage, and buying the furniture

10054.text:
which had disappeared in the wake of his wife,
he had never been able to save any money since

10058.text:
the time of those disastrous ventures, and
till his wages began to come in he was obliged

10064.text:
to live in the narrowest way.
After buying a book or two he could not even

10068.text:
afford himself a fire; and when the nights
reeked with the raw and cold air from the

10073.text:
Meadows he sat over his lamp in a great-coat,
hat, and woollen gloves.

10079.text:
From his window he could perceive the spire
of the cathedral, and the ogee dome under

10084.text:
which resounded the great bell of the city.
The tall tower, tall belfry windows, and tall

10090.text:
pinnacles of the college by the bridge he
could also get a glimpse of by going to the

10096.text:
staircase. These objects he used as stimulants
when his faith in the future was dim.

10101.text:
Like enthusiasts in general he made no inquiries
into details of procedure.

10106.text:
Picking up general notions from casual acquaintance,
he never dwelt upon them.

10111.text:
For the present, he said to himself, the one
thing necessary was to get ready by accumulating

10116.text:
money and knowledge, and await whatever chances
were afforded to such an one of becoming a

10121.text:
son of the University.
"For wisdom is a defence, and money is a defence;

10126.text:
but the excellency of knowledge is, that wisdom
giveth life to them that have it."

10132.text:
His desire absorbed him, and left no part
of him to weigh its practicability.

10137.text:
At this time he received a nervously anxious
letter from his poor old aunt, on the subject

10142.text:
which had previously distressed her—a fear
that Jude would not be strong-minded enough

10146.text:
to keep away from his cousin Sue Bridehead
and her relations.

10150.text:
Sue's father, his aunt believed, had gone
back to London, but the girl remained at Christminster.

10157.text:
To make her still more objectionable she was
an artist or designer of some sort in what

10162.text:
was called an ecclesiastical warehouse, which
was a perfect seed-bed of idolatry, and she

10167.text:
was no doubt abandoned to mummeries on that
account—if not quite a Papist. (Miss Drusilla

10173.text:
Fawley was of her date, Evangelical.)
As Jude was rather on an intellectual track

10178.text:
than a theological, this news of Sue's probable
opinions did not much influence him one way

10183.text:
or the other, but the clue to her whereabouts
was decidedly interesting. With an altogether

10189.text:
singular pleasure he walked at his earliest
spare minutes past the shops answering to

10194.text:
his great-aunt's description; and beheld in
one of them a young girl sitting behind a

10199.text:
desk, who was suspiciously like the original
of the portrait.

10203.text:
He ventured to enter on a trivial errand,
and having made his purchase lingered on the

10208.text:
scene.
The shop seemed to be kept entirely by women.

10212.text:
It contained Anglican books, stationery, texts,
and fancy goods: little plaster angels on

10218.text:
brackets, Gothic-framed pictures of saints,
ebony crosses that were almost crucifixes,

10224.text:
prayer-books that were almost missals. He
felt very shy of looking at the girl in the

10229.text:
desk; she was so pretty that he could not
believe it possible that she should belong

10233.text:
to him.
Then she spoke to one of the two older women

10237.text:
behind the counter; and he recognized in the
accents certain qualities of his own voice;

10243.text:
softened and sweetened, but his own.
What was she doing? He stole a glance round.

10250.text:
Before her lay a piece of zinc, cut to the
shape of a scroll three or four feet long,

10255.text:
and coated with a dead-surface paint on one
side.

10258.text:
Hereon she was designing or illuminating,
in characters of Church text, the single word

10264.text:
A L L E L U J A
"A sweet, saintly, Christian business, hers!"

10269.text:
thought he.
Her presence here was now fairly enough explained,

10274.text:
her skill in work of this sort having no doubt
been acquired from her father's occupation

10278.text:
as an ecclesiastical worker in metal.
The lettering on which she was engaged was

10283.text:
clearly intended to be fixed up in some chancel
to assist devotion.

10288.text:
He came out.
It would have been easy to speak to her there

10291.text:
and then, but it seemed scarcely honourable
towards his aunt to disregard her request

10296.text:
so incontinently.
She had used him roughly, but she had brought

10300.text:
him up: and the fact of her being powerless
to control him lent a pathetic force to a

10305.text:
wish that would have been inoperative as an
argument.

10309.text:
So Jude gave no sign.
He would not call upon Sue just yet.

10314.text:
He had other reasons against doing so when
he had walked away.

10317.text:
She seemed so dainty beside himself in his
rough working-jacket and dusty trousers that

10323.text:
he felt he was as yet unready to encounter
her, as he had felt about Mr. Phillotson.

10329.text:
And how possible it was that she had inherited
the antipathies of her family, and would scorn

10333.text:
him, as far as a Christian could, particularly
when he had told her that unpleasant part

10338.text:
of his history which had resulted in his becoming
enchained to one of her own sex whom she would

10344.text:
certainly not admire.
Thus he kept watch over her, and liked to

10348.text:
feel she was there. The consciousness of her
living presence stimulated him.

10353.text:
But she remained more or less an ideal character,
about whose form he began to weave curious

10359.text:
and fantastic day-dreams.
Between two and three weeks afterwards Jude

10364.text:
was engaged with some more men, outside Crozier
College in Old-time Street, in getting a block

10369.text:
of worked freestone from a waggon across the
pavement, before hoisting it to the parapet

10374.text:
which they were repairing.
Standing in position the head man said, "Spaik

10380.text:
when he heave! He-ho!"
And they heaved.

10384.text:
All of a sudden, as he lifted, his cousin
stood close to his elbow, pausing a moment

10389.text:
on the bend of her foot till the obstructing
object should have been removed.

10394.text:
She looked right into his face with liquid,
untranslatable eyes, that combined, or seemed

10399.text:
to him to combine, keenness with tenderness,
and mystery with both, their expression, as

10405.text:
well as that of her lips, taking its life
from some words just spoken to a companion,

10410.text:
and being carried on into his face quite unconsciously.
She no more observed his presence than that

10416.text:
of the dust-motes which his manipulations
raised into the sunbeams.

10422.text:
His closeness to her was so suggestive that
he trembled, and turned his face away with

10426.text:
a shy instinct to prevent her recognizing
him, though as she had never once seen him

10432.text:
she could not possibly do so; and might very
well never have heard even his name.

10437.text:
He could perceive that though she was a country-girl
at bottom, a latter girlhood of some years

10441.text:
in London, and a womanhood here, had taken
all rawness out of her.

10446.text:
When she was gone he continued his work, reflecting
on her.

10451.text:
He had been so caught by her influence that
he had taken no count of her general mould

10455.text:
and build.
He remembered now that she was not a large

10459.text:
figure, that she was light and slight, of
the type dubbed elegant. That was about all

10464.text:
he had seen.
There was nothing statuesque in her; all was

10468.text:
nervous motion.
She was mobile, living, yet a painter might

10473.text:
not have called her handsome or beautiful.
But the much that she was surprised him.

10479.text:
She was quite a long way removed from the
rusticity that was his.

10483.text:
How could one of his cross-grained, unfortunate,
almost accursed stock, have contrived to reach

10489.text:
this pitch of niceness?
London had done it, he supposed.

10494.text:
From this moment the emotion which had been
accumulating in his breast as the bottled-up

10499.text:
effect of solitude and the poetized locality
he dwelt in, insensibly began to precipitate

10505.text:
itself on this half-visionary form; and he
perceived that, whatever his obedient wish

10510.text:
in a contrary direction, he would soon be
unable to resist the desire to make himself

10515.text:
known to her.
He affected to think of her quite in a family

10519.text:
way, since there were crushing reasons why
he should not and could not think of her in

10524.text:
any other.
The first reason was that he was married,

10527.text:
and it would be wrong. The second was that
they were cousins.

10531.text:
It was not well for cousins to fall in love
even when circumstances seemed to favour the

10536.text:
passion. The third: even were he free, in
a family like his own where marriage usually

10542.text:
meant a tragic sadness, marriage with a blood-relation
would duplicate the adverse conditions, and

10549.text:
a tragic sadness might be intensified to a
tragic horror.

10553.text:
Therefore, again, he would have to think of
Sue with only a relation's mutual interest

10559.text:
in one belonging to him; regard her in a practical
way as some one to be proud of; to talk and

10566.text:
nod to; later on, to be invited to tea by,
the emotion spent on her being rigorously

10571.text:
that of a kinsman and well-wisher.
So would she be to him a kindly star, an elevating

10578.text:
power, a companion in Anglican worship, a
tender friend.
